items.title: numpy array written as strings
items.body:
numpy arrays with float values are written as strings. When converted to a `list` of floats, it's all going well.

MWE:
```python
import toml
import numpy


numpy.random.seed(0)
x = numpy.random.rand(3)
a = {"a": x}
print(toml.dumps(a))

b = {"b": x.tolist()}
print(toml.dumps(b))
```
```toml
a = [ "0.5488135039273248", "0.7151893663724195", "0.6027633760716439",]

b = [ 0.5488135039273248, 0.7151893663724195, 0.6027633760716439,]

```

items.title: group name character constraints
items.body:
First, Thank you for the excellent toml paser.
I have a problem here
When I parse the toml
```
[测试]
url = "test"
```
I got an error: 
toml.decoder.TomlDecodeError: Invalid group name '测试'. Try quoting it.

I read the decoder.py, I find the constraints of the group name here
```
_groupname_re = re.compile(r'^[A-Za-z0-9_-]+$')
```
I don't know why constraints here. If I modify it to 
```
_groupname_re = re.compile(r'^.*?$')
```
Everything is ok. 

So, is it a bug or the special design.

with `toml==0.10.0` yields

```ipython
In [2]: toml.load("Cargo.toml")
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
~/.local/share/virtualenvs/mozilla-depends-AEg89WL-/lib/python3.7/site-packages/toml/decoder.py in loads(s, _dict, decoder)                                                                                       
    455                 ret = decoder.load_line(line, currentlevel, multikey,
--> 456                                         multibackslash)
    457             except ValueError as err:

~/.local/share/virtualenvs/mozilla-depends-AEg89WL-/lib/python3.7/site-packages/toml/decoder.py in load_inline_object(self, line, currentlevel, multikey, multibackslash)

~/.local/share/virtualenvs/mozilla-depends-AEg89WL-/lib/python3.7/site-packages/toml/decoder.py in load_line(self, line, currentlevel, multikey, multibackslash)

<ipython-input-2-ce4beea9cb39> in <module>

~/.local/share/virtualenvs/mozilla-depends-AEg89WL-/lib/python3.7/site-packages/toml/decoder.py in load(f, _dict, decoder)
```

However, parsing with the two values reversed is no problem:


I have a hard time understanding what exactly is going sideways in the parser, but I think that it may be related to trying to parse that inline dict as inline table, as is being hinted to by the following observations:

items.title: Subkeys are not dumped together
items.body:
This may not actually be a bug, but it would be convenient if the parent keys were grouped together.

Instead of 
```
[vwefoin.sfxsfx]
ip = "8.8.8.8"

[mxvin.mxvin_1]
key = "value"

[mxvin.mxvin_2]
key = "value"

[mxvin.mxvin_3]
key = "value"

[mxvin.mxvin_4]
key = "value"

[vwefoin.sfxsfx.memes]
obiwan = "hello there"
```

It should dump like this:
```
[vwefoin.sfxsfx]
ip = "8.8.8.8"

[vwefoin.sfxsfx.memes]
obiwan = "hello there"

[mxvin.mxvin_1]
key = "value"

[mxvin.mxvin_2]
key = "value"

[mxvin.mxvin_3]
key = "value"

[mxvin.mxvin_4]
key = "value"
```

If previous behavior is also desirable, perhaps support different sorting policies?

items.title: toml.dumps unable to detect circular references
items.body:
`toml.dumps` chokes if it is passed a (valid) python object with circular references:

```
>>> a = {}
>>> a['self'] = a
>>> toml.dumps(a)
```

hangs forever with 100% CPU.

For reference `json.dumps(a)` raises `ValueError: Circular reference detected` while pickle and yaml serialise circular references without problem, e.g.:

```
>>> b = pickle.loads(pickle.dumps(a))
>>> b['self'] is b
True
```

Although it's for sure insane to feed recursive objects to `toml.dumps`, maybe raising an exception is better than an endless loop. In fact it is possible that a not so evident circular reference is created and fed to `toml.dumps` by error.

items.title: Hex integer values aren't decoded
items.body:
TOML v0.5.0 supports hex/octal/bin integer values: https://github.com/toml-lang/toml#integer (TOML v0.4.0 doesn't support these).

python-toml 0.9.6 doesn't support hex/octal/bin integer value although link to TOML 0.5.0 was bumped (https://github.com/uiri/toml/commit/a444a3659ea06d62fa3aeac9595946ebcbec13ae#diff-88b99bb28683bd5b7e3a204826ead112).
BurntSushi/toml-test doesn't have tests for TOML v0.5.0 see BurntSushi/toml-test#49 so it's not clear why python-toml is considered to support TOML 0.5.0

```
[vlotorev@host ~]$ python3 -c "import toml; toml.loads('a=0x1')"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/vlotorev/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/toml.py", line 400, in loads
    multibackslash)
  File "/home/vlotorev/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/toml.py", line 516, in _load_line
    raise ValueError("Invalid date or number")
ValueError: Invalid date or number

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/vlotorev/.local/lib/python3.4/site-packages/toml.py", line 402, in loads
    raise TomlDecodeError(str(err))
toml.TomlDecodeError: Invalid date or number
```

the same error fires for 'a=0b1' and 'a=0o1'.

Note:

items.title: inf and nan not supported
items.body:
Infinity and Not-a-Number are described in the [Float section](https://github.com/toml-lang/toml#float) of the TOML spec.

`toml` doesn't recognize them as floating point numbers and tries to use `int` for conversion as can be seen in this minimal example:
```python
>>> toml.loads("""
... a = inf
... """)
Traceback (most recent call last):
...
[...]/site-packages/toml.py", line 664, in _load_value
    v = int(v)
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: 'inf'
```
Same error for `nan`, and also for arrays containing them.

I'm using `toml` 0.9.4.

items.title: load_date() in decoder.py not handling missing time zone
items.body:
I wrote a naive datetime (e.g. obtained with datetime.datetime.now()) to a toml file using dump and when I try to load it back in I get an error. Here is a simple demonstration in interactive python3:

```
Python 3.6.6 (default, Jul 19 2018, 14:25:17) 
[GCC 8.1.1 20180712 (Red Hat 8.1.1-5)] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import toml
>>> import datetime
>>> d = datetime.datetime.now()
>>> config = {"mydate":d}
>>> t = toml.dumps(config)
>>> t
'mydate = 2018-09-14T21:37:45.361006\n'
>>> config2 = toml.loads(t)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 400, in loads
    multibackslash)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 540, in _load_line
    value, vtype = _load_value(pair[1], _dict, strictly_valid)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 723, in _load_value
    parsed_date = _load_date(v)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 570, in _load_date
    tz = TomlTz(tzval)
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'tzval' referenced before assignment
>>> 
```

My case has no time zone data and therefore there is no Z, so it hits the *if* at line 470 and then jumps to the *else* at line 473. It doesn't satisfy the "if" at 475 or the *elif* at 479, so when it gets to 483, there is no assigned value for tzval.

It seems that there should be an *else* at 483 (following the *elif* block) to handle naive datetime instances with no Z in the string.

I am able to work around the problem by using UTC dates with time zone info, obtainable with:

```
import pytz
import datetime
d = datetime.datetime.utcnow().replace(tzinfo=pytz.utc)
```

Otherwise, thanks for the great toml implementation!

items.title: float resolves to datetime on load
items.body:
>>> toml.loads('z = 3853110.0341112586')
{'z': datetime.datetime(3853, 10, 3, 11, 25, 6)}

https://github.com/uiri/toml/blob/a444a3659ea06d62fa3aeac9595946ebcbec13ae/toml/decoder.py#L498

Should probably check if works as other types first, or if the separators between YYYY MM DD etc. are also numbers. If they are numbers, probably not a datetime.

items.title: Cannot load a dumped `dict` containing `set`
items.body:
Hello there.

I looked the issues but I didn't find one that exactly matches this. If there is, I apologize for opening a duplicate.

The following code uses the most recent code in this repositories' master with python 3.6.5:

```python
>>> import toml
>>> dict_with_set = {'filled_set': set({1, 2}), 'empty_set': set({})}
>>> toml.dumps(dict_with_set)
'filled_set = {1, 2}\nempty_set = set()\n'
>>> toml.loads(toml.dumps(dict_with_set))
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/user/dev/tools/toml/toml/decoder.py", line 545, in load_inline_object
    _, value = candidate_group.split('=', 1)
ValueError: not enough values to unpack (expected 2, got 1)

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/user/dev/tools/toml/toml/decoder.py", line 419, in loads
    multibackslash)
  File "/Users/user/dev/tools/toml/toml/decoder.py", line 611, in load_line
    value, vtype = self.load_value(pair[1], strictly_valid)
  File "/Users/user/dev/tools/toml/toml/decoder.py", line 688, in load_value
    self.load_inline_object(v, inline_object)
  File "/Users/user/dev/tools/toml/toml/decoder.py", line 547, in load_inline_object
    raise ValueError("Invalid inline table encountered")
ValueError: Invalid inline table encountered

During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred:

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/user/dev/tools/toml/toml/decoder.py", line 421, in loads
    raise TomlDecodeError(str(err), original, pos)
toml.decoder.TomlDecodeError: Invalid inline table encountered (line 1 column 1 char 0)
```

I don't know if this is considered in `loads`, but maybe it relates to the fact that `set`'s `__repr__` and `__str__` use braces when outputing:

```python
>>> s = set({1, 2})
>>> repr(s)
'{1, 2}'
>>> str(s)
'{1, 2}'
```

items.title: dotted keys aren't supported
items.body:
The [TOML spec](https://github.com/toml-lang/toml#keys) specifies that the following syntax is valid:

`a.b.c = "hello"`

to give you a structure like

`{'a': {'b': {'c': 'hello'}}}`

the `toml` python library just raises an exception when parsing a key, saying that a `.` is unexpected and that the key should be quoted.

items.title: Encoder will emit invalid Nones
items.body:
```
>>> toml.dumps({'title': [ None ]})
'title = [ None,]\n'
```

This is not valid TOML, since TOML does not allow barewords (and indeed doesn't have any concept of null/none anyway). Sure enough,

```
>>> toml.loads(toml.dumps({'title': [ None ]}))

  File "/home/tom/dev/toml/toml/decoder.py", line 395, in loads
```

items.title: dumping should fail for unsupported data types
items.body:
At present, if an object of unsupported data type (e.g. tuple) is provided to `_dump_value`, it is simply returned as-is and is written to the toml string or file in its string representation (but without quotes). This gives the user the impression that there is nothing wrong with the supplied data. However, not only is the created toml string/file invalid, but toml.load[s] cannot read in the object. 

Propose raising error in `_dump_value` if `type(v) not in dump_funcs`.

Example current (bad) behavior:
```
>>> config_start = {'the_tuple': (3, 4, 5)}
>>> toml_conf = toml.dumps(config_start)
>>> config_end = toml.loads(toml_conf)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/shared/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 373, in loads
    multibackslash)
  File "/shared/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 478, in _load_line
    value, vtype = _load_value(pair[1], _dict, strictly_valid)
  File "/shared/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 664, in _load_value
    v = int(v)
ValueError: invalid literal for int() with base 10: '(3, 4, 5)'
```

Expected behavior:
```
>>> config_start = {'the_tuple': (3, 4, 5)}
>>> toml_conf = toml.dumps(config_start)
Traceback blah...
    blah...
    blah...
TypeError: `tuple` type not supported in TOML.
```

items.title: `toml.loads` spins forever parsing a table entry with whitespace and dots
items.body:
On 0.9.4 (and current master), adding a table entry value with (unnecessary) padding whitespace and dots (which looks like the spec allows?) seems to end up in an infinite loop:

```
Python 3.6.4 (default, Dec 19 2017, 14:48:12) 
[GCC 4.8.5 20150623 (Red Hat 4.8.5-16)] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import toml
>>> toml.__version__
'0.9.4'
>>> toml.loads('[ "white.space" ]')
```

At that point, it spins forever (or until I ctrl-c it).

items.title: `toml.loads` seems to parse complex keys incorrectly
items.body:
toml: 0.9.3.1

```
>>> import toml
>>> toml.loads('key=66')
{'key': 66}
>>> toml.loads('"key"=66')
{'key': 66}
>>> toml.loads('"key !"=66')
{'key !': 66}
>>> toml.loads('"key !="= 56')
{'"key !': '= 5'}
```
- `=` seems to have higher precedence than `"`
- Even with that, it seems to not fail with the `"= 56` lacking a closing `"`

items.title: Dumping non-ASCII bytes produces gibberish
items.body:
```
>>> import toml; print toml.dumps({'username': 'שלום'})
username = "\u00d7\u00a9\u00d7\u009c\u00d7\u0095\u00d7\u009d"
```

where that value (which you can get back again via loads obviously) is `u'\xd7\xa9\xd7\x9c\xd7\x95\xd7\x9d'` which is very different from `'\xd7\xa9\xd7\x9c\xd7\x95\xd7\x9d'` (the bytes, which are what was sent in), and which as unicode are u'\u05e9\u05dc\u05d5\u05dd'.

There should really be only 2 ways to treat passing in bytes there, either it should assume some encoding ([which is what the `json` module does, and allows you to override which encoding](https://docs.python.org/2/library/json.html#json.dump)) or it should just raise an exception and always ask users to provide unicode objects.

items.title: Empty string in a list breaks parser
items.body:
This is with version 0.9.3

Here is a minimal example that breaks the parser:

```python
import toml
toml.loads("hello = ['',]")
```

This results in the output:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/mbentley/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 373, in loads
    multibackslash)
  File "/home/mbentley/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 478, in _load_line
    value, vtype = _load_value(pair[1], _dict, strictly_valid)
  File "/home/mbentley/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 637, in _load_value
    return (_load_array(v, _dict), "array")
  File "/home/mbentley/anaconda3/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 714, in _load_array
    while ab[-1] != ab[0] or (ab[0] == ab[1] == ab[2] and
IndexError: string index out of range
```

It's not only because of the trailing comma.  Here is another example that causes the same problem

```python
import toml
toml.loads("hello = ['', 'world']")
```

But you may notice that it works if the empty string is at the end of the list

```python
import toml
toml.loads("hello = ['world', '']")
```

For my application, I need to be able to specify an empty string in a list.  For now, I can put it at the end.  This used to work in older versions of the toml package.  Specifically, I have confirmed it working in version 0.9.1.

items.title: Fails to serialize dictionaries that have numerical keys
items.body:
The toml library fails to serialize dictionaries that have numerical keys. 

**Expected behavior:** Numerical keys in the dictionary to serialize will be converted to strings when `toml.dumps` or `toml.dump` is called. (Like the behavior of the equivalent json functions `json.dumps` and `json.dump`).

**Actual behavior:** `toml.dumps` and `toml.dump` both return a `TypeError`.

**Example** (toml version 0.9.2, python 2.7.6):
```
import toml
d = {1: "stuff"}
toml.dumps(d)
```

**Expected output:**
```
>>> import toml
>>> toml.dumps(d)
'{"1": "stuff"}'
```

**Actual Output:**
```
>>> import toml
>>> d = {1: "stuff"}
>>> toml.dumps(d)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/jakory/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toml.py", line 597, in dumps
    addtoretval, sections = _dump_sections(o, "")
  File "/home/jakory/.local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/toml.py", line 619, in _dump_sections
    if not re.match(r'^[A-Za-z0-9_-]+$', section):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/re.py", line 137, in match
    return _compile(pattern, flags).match(string)
TypeError: expected string or buffer
```

items.title: Error when parsing table of arrays of tables of arrays of tables of tables where the lowest array has multiple entries
items.body:
Here's an example of such a toml file:

```
[[a]]
    [[a.b]]
        [a.b.c]
            d = "val0"
    [[a.b]]
        [a.b.c]
            d = "val1"
```

The library has no problem producing the toml output from a python object constructed like so, but on attempting to parse it, it errors with "An implicitly defined table can't be an array". That does not seem to be the case in this file.

Removing one layer of table/array allows it to be read.

To be fair, the TOML to JSON tool I usually use to validate my TOML doesn't work correctly with this eiither: https://toml-to-json.matiaskorhonen.fi/, but I can't find anything in the spec that should limit this use case.

Here's that same toml input being dumped from a python object and then loaded.

```
import toml

toml_dict = { # TABLE
    "a": [ # ARRAY
        { # TABLE
            "b": [ # ARRAY
                { # TABLE
                    "c": {"d": "val0"}  # TABLE
                },
                { # TABLE
                    "c": {"d": "val1"}  # TABLE
                }
            ]
        }
    ]
}

toml.loads(toml.dumps(toml_dict))
```

items.title: Failure to decode an inline table with a string that has embedded square brackets
items.body:
I'm not sure the issue headline captures it exactly, hopefully the examples below make it more clear. I think I narrowed it down to a corner case of a) an inline table; b) the inline table having more than one item; and c) one of the items in the table being a string with embedded square brackets.

Repro:

```
import toml

WORKING_TOMLS = [
"""
a = [
    {x = '1', y = 'no embedded brackets'},
]
""",

"""
a = [
    {x = '1', y = 'embedded {} brackets'},
]
""",

"""
a = [
    {y = 'embedded [] brackets'},
]
""",

"""
[[a]]
x = '1'
y = 'embedded [] brackets'
"""
]

BROKEN_TOML = """
a = [
    {x = '1', y = 'embedded [] brackets'},
]
"""

for working_toml in WORKING_TOMLS:
    print(toml.loads(working_toml))

print(toml.loads(BROKEN_TOML))

```

Expected:

```
{'a': [{'x': '1', 'y': 'no embedded brackets'}]}
{'a': [{'x': '1', 'y': 'embedded {} brackets'}]}
{'a': [{'y': 'embedded [] brackets'}]}
{'a': [{'x': '1', 'y': 'embedded [] brackets'}]}
{'a': [{'x': '1', 'y': 'embedded [] brackets'}]}
```

Actual:

```
{'a': [{'x': '1', 'y': 'no embedded brackets'}]}
{'a': [{'x': '1', 'y': 'embedded {} brackets'}]}
{'a': [{'y': 'embedded [] brackets'}]}
{'a': [{'x': '1', 'y': 'embedded [] brackets'}]}
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 38, in <module>
    print(toml.loads(BROKEN_TOML))
  File "/home/zack/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 370, in loads
    multibackslash)
  File "/home/zack/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 475, in _load_line
    value, vtype = _load_value(pair[1], _dict, strictly_valid)
  File "/home/zack/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 634, in _load_value
    return (_load_array(v, _dict), "array")
  File "/home/zack/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 737, in _load_array
    nval, ntype = _load_value(a[i], _dict)
  File "/home/zack/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 637, in _load_value
    _load_inline_object(v, inline_object, _dict)
  File "/home/zack/test/venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/toml.py", line 395, in _load_inline_object
    candidate_groups[0] = candidate_group + "," + candidate_groups[0]
IndexError: list index out of range
```

Environment:
- Discovered with Python 3.6.1 and toml 0.9.2
- Verified still reproducible with Python 3.6.1 and latest master branch of this repo
- Also reproducible on Python 2.7.13 (with both toml 0.9.2 and the master branch)

items.title: Broken parsing within lists
items.body:
After using toml very happily for most of our new applications and services, we seem to have hit a parsing bug for certain strings within lists.

```python
>>> toml.loads("""
ignored = [
    '\w{6}$'
]

broken = ['\w{6}$']

ok = [
    '\w\w\w\w\w\w$'
]
""")
{u'broken': [u'\\w{6'], u'ignored': [], u'ok': [u'\\w\\w\\w\\w\\w\\w$']}
```
As the example shows there are two errors. They seem to be escaping and white space related.

- The *ignored* list containing the `\w{6}` value is empty. Even with more elements in it, none gets in the list.
- The *broken* list conflictive string `\w{6}` is missing last two characters.

This fails consistently in *Python 2.7.12* and *Python 3.5.2*.
Used version is *toml (0.9.2)* which is the last one AFAIK.

items.title: datetimes are serialized incorrectly
items.body:
Hi there, I can't use uiri/toml implementation because of this deal-breaker:

```
>>> from datetime import datetime
>>> tz = pytz.timezone('America/Chicago')
>>> dt_naive = datetime(2017, 6, 6, 12, 34, 56)
>>> dt_aware = tz.localize(dt_naive)
>>> d = {'dt': dt_aware}
>>> print(dt_aware)
2017-06-06 12:34:56-05:00
```

So, I have non-naive datetime in the data.  

```
>>> import toml
>>> toml.dumps(d)
'dt = 2017-06-06T12:34:56Z\n'
                         ^
                         |
                       UTC?!
```

The Z here indicates Zulu time; the serialized datetime is indicated as UTC.  Outputting a naive datetime would perhaps be understandable, but indicating an _incorrect_ timezone is really bad.  

Other libraries don't make this mistake:

```
>>> import pytoml
>>> pytoml.dumps(d)
'dt = 2017-06-06T12:34:56-5.00.0\n'
>>> import yaml
>>> yaml.dump(d)
"{dt: !!timestamp '2017-06-06 12:34:56-05:00'}\n"
```

items.title: Add warning on non-existent filename passed in list to load
items.body: One possible use for `load` involves passing a list of filenames. It is possible for some of those filenames to be valid while other filenames in the list are invalid. `load` should generate a warning about these invalid filenames while proceeding normally with the valid filenames.


items.title: Ordering dumps
items.body: At the moment dumps does not care about the order of the items in the passed dictionary.  However, when passing an ordered mapping like ``collections.OrderedDictionary`` it should probably try to preserve the order order in the outputted string as well.

items.title: Loading from list of filenames should return a list
items.body:
Related to [this section](https://github.com/uiri/toml/blob/master/toml.py#L41-L48) of code.
When calling `.loads([])` my expectation would be to get a list, not a dictionary with all the values merged together. I do not really see a use case for the latter. It also causes unexpected rewrites. 

Example:
```Python
with open('file1.toml', 'w') as f:
    f.write('a = 1\n')

with open('file2.toml', 'w') as f:
    f.write('a = 2\n')

tom = toml.load(['file1.toml', 'file2.toml']);
print(tom) # Prints {'a': 2} 
```

items.title: Preserving inline tables
items.body:
Hey @uiri, are there any plans to support preserving inline tables in the `dumps` function. If not would you be open to a PR implementing such functionality?

Right now, I have a project with users supplying TOML, often using the inline tables syntax:

`value = {extra = ["values",]}`

While `loads` handles this just fine, serializing back to TOML creates a subsection. This is creating maintainability problems, in some cases, since things are moving around in the TOML file unexpectedly. It would be nice if the data structure was written back out as it was ingested, if possible.

Thanks for your consideration!

items.title: Indentation and whitespaces are being stripped away in multiline strings
items.body:
Hi,

the current implementation of the parser strips away whitespace from all lines using `strip()`.
To reproduce use this snippet:

``` python
import toml

t = '''
foo = """
test
  test
  test2
test3
    test5
    test6
test7
"""
'''

p = toml.loads(t)
print p["foo"]
```

**Acutal Output**

```
test
test
test2
test3
test5
test6
test7
```

**Expected Output**

```
test
  test
  test2
test3
    test5
    test6
test7
```

This violates the `toml` spec (see https://github.com/toml-lang/toml#string)

> Multi-line basic strings are surrounded by three quotation marks on each side and allow newlines. A newline immediately following the opening delimiter will be trimmed. All other whitespace and newline characters remain intact.

furthermore

> A newline immediately following the opening delimiter will be trimmed. All other content between the delimiters is interpreted as-is without modification.
